title: German submarine U-962
text:
German submarine "U-962" was a <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine">Type VIIC</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> built for <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. Her keel was laid at the yards of Blohm & Voss in <a href="Hamburg">Hamburg</a> on 7 April 1942. <a href="Ceremonial%20ship%20launching">Launched</a> on 17 December 1942, she was formally <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 11 February 1943 and given to "Oblt.z.S." Ernst Liesberg, who commanded the submarine on both of her active war patrols.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIC">German Type VIIC submarines</a> were preceded by the shorter <a href="German%20Type%20VII%20submarine%23Type%20VIIB">Type VIIB submarines</a>. "U-962" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. She had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="Germaniawerft">Germaniawerft</a> F46 four-stroke, six-cylinder <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="Brown%2C%20Boveri%20%26amp%3B%20Cie">Brown, Boveri & Cie</a> GG UB 720/8 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-962" was fitted with five <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and one at the stern), fourteen <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="8.8%20cm%20SK%20C/35%20naval%20gun">SK C/35 naval gun</a>, 220 rounds, and one twin <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> <a href="anti-aircraft%20gun">anti-aircraft gun</a>. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of between forty-four and sixty.
War patrols.
After her working up period ended, "U-962" departed <a href="Kiel">Kiel</a> for <a href="Bergen">Bergen</a>, Norway on 23 September 1943, arriving on 27 September. After a stay of about a month, the crew cast off on their first active patrol 3 November 1943. This 56-day cruise in the mid-Atlantic Ocean yielded no targets and the patrol was terminated at <a href="St.%20Nazaire">St. Nazaire</a> in occupied France on 28 December 1943.
On 14 February 1944, "U-962" departed St. Nazaire on her second and last patrol. She again cruised in the central Atlantic for 55 days until she ran afoul of the British <a href="Black%20Swan%20class%20sloop">sloops</a> and and sunk in position by depth charges. There were no survivors.
Wolfpacks.
"U-962" took part in five <a href="Wolfpack%20%28naval%20tactic%29">wolfpack</a>s, namely.
